## Eviction Prevention and Emergency Assistance   for Rent, Utilities, Food and Employment

MAC believes in the benefits of providing prevention assistance to low income working households in 10 zip codes in Midtown and Downtown Atlanta. In a welcoming environment, MAC encourages self-sufficiency while aiding in the most important basic needs.

## Food Pantry Assistance

MAC has a client choice food pantry that provides non-perishable food and fresh meat and produce for households experiencing a temporary shortage. Our neighbors can choose the groceries that best meet their family’s needs.

[Read more](https://midtownassistancecenter.org/food-pantry-assistance/)

## Job Support

MAC provides required uniform items including clothing, footwear, etc. needed for different industries including hospitality, construction, and service. We also provide MARTA cards to help with transportation to and from work.

[Read more](https://midtownassistancecenter.org/job-support/)

## Emergency Rent and Utility Assistance

MAC helps low-income, working households that are in a temporary financial crisis. Our assistance works to prevent eviction and disconnection of electricity, gas, and water

[Read more](https://midtownassistancecenter.org/emergency-rent-and-utility-assistance/)

# Community  Ministries

First Presbyterian Church is committed to embodying Christ’s love in the community around us. We offer a number of services to individuals who are experiencing homelessness, transitioning, and in need.

## Connection Services

- #### Computer Lab






A fully functional computer lab to use for your varied personal needs.



**Offered**: Wednesdays 1:00 p.m. - 3:00 p.m.



Classes offered every Wednesday with Atlanta Center for Self Sufficiency on a first come, first serve basis.

- #### Mail & Fellowship






Sign up to receive mail and/or pick up mail using the church address.



**Offered**: Sundays from 8:00 a.m. to 11:00 am or Mondays - Thursdays from 1:00 p.m. - 3:00 p.m., no appointment necessary!



**Required**: Provide picture ID and sign the “Guidelines for Receipt of Mail.” You should be able to show ID each time you come in to pick up mail.



**To Sign Up**: Simply come by and fill out a form!


## Food Services

- #### Prayer Breakfast






Come and join us for a hot, homemade breakfast consisting of grits, sausage, biscuits, jelly, and hard-boiled eggs.



**Offered**: Sundays 6:30 a.m. - 7:30 a.m.



Enter via the 16th Street Entrance, through the double doors!

- #### Venable Food Market






A food pantry dedicated to supporting the residents of Midtown Atlanta. The food market is open weekly, for neighbors to receive food twice a month, select and receive essential groceries at no cost.



[Click here for more information on our food market!](https://www.firstpresatl.org/foodmarket)


## Hygiene Services

- #### Hygiene Closet






Provides items such as toiletries, underwear, socks, and others.



**Offered**: Mondays and Thursdays from 1:00 p.m. - 3:00 p.m.

- #### Clothing Corner






An opportunity to receive clean clothing once every seven days.



**Offered**: Mondays and Thursdays from 1:00 p.m. - 3:00 p.m.



Sign-Up for a time slot starts at 12:45 p.m. on the same day.

- #### Showers






A 15 minute shower after you are given a Hygiene kit (includes toiletries, washcloth, and towel) and get to pick a new set of clothing.



**For Men**:



  - Wednesdays from 4:00 p.m. - 6:00 p.m.

    - Sign-Up starts at 12:45 p.m.

- #### Haircuts






Free haircuts provided by Atlanta Technical College



**Offered**: Wednesdays from 5:00 p.m. - 7:00 p.m.



Sign-Up starts at 12:45 p.m.



**Seasonally Available**

- #### Foot Care






Foot Care volunteers provide non-clinical care, helping to keep clients' feet clean, healthy, and comfortable.



**Offered**: Twice a month, on Wednesdays from 4:00 - 6:00 p.m.



First come, first serve, space is limited.



For questions regarding footcare and occurrences, please email [**jivey@firstpresatl.org.**](mailto:jivey@firstpresatl.org?subject=Client%20Foot%20Care%20Information)


## Social Services

Get assistance receiving vital records.

**Offered**: Monday - Thursday from 10:00 a.m. - 12:00 p.m.

**Sign-Up** for same day appointments starting at 10:00 a.m.

Walk-In appointments available on a first come, first serve.

- #### Food Stamps






Bring a working, in-service phone. If you do not have one, you will have to visit the office at 1249 Donald Lee Hollowell Pkwy NW, Atlanta, GA, 30318.

- #### Birth Certificates






We can assist with birth certificates for individuals born anywhere in the U.S. We are unable to assist with requests for individuals born outside the U.S., unless they were born abroad to U.S. citizens.

- #### ID Voucher






Vouchers cover the cost of getting a state ID. It does not cover fees for a driver’s license.

- #### Social Security Cards






You need either an ID or a TB card to receive a social security card. If you have a working phone, call and make the appointment with the Social Security Office at 866-931-9946.


We cannot help with Marta Cards, financial assistance, bus tickets, job search, employment assistance, or ordering cell phones. While we cannot assist with these services, we do have resource lists available for places that do!

## Volunteer Opportunities

If you are looking to volunteer in any capacity with First Presbyterian Community Ministries, please navigate to our Volunteer Sign Up portal below!

If you have any questions regarding volunteer opportunities or would like a tour of the Community Ministries work area, please email Jacob Ivey at [jivey@firstpresatl.org](mailto:jivey@firstpresatl.org?subject=Volunteer%20Opportunities%20).

[Volunteer Sign Up Portal](https://firstpresbyterianchurchofatlanta.volunteerlocal.com/volunteer/?id=89928)

Volunteer options include the following:

- #### Clothing Corner






Volunteers are needed to staff the Community Ministries Clothing corner on **Mondays and Thursdays from 1:00 p.m. to 3:00 p.m.** Volunteers can expect to interact with clients by helping them select items of clothing while also organizing and sorting clothing.



**Location**: 1st Floor of the Smith Building, 1328 Peachtree Street, N.E. Atlanta, GA 30309

- #### Hygiene Closet






Volunteers are needed to staff the Hospitality Closet on **Mondays and Thursdays from 1:00 p.m. to 3:00 p.m.**. The volunteer will distribute items from the closet such as tooth brushes, razors, blankets, etc. Additionally, volunteers will aid in keeping the closet organized and restocking with donated items.



**Location**: 1st Floor of the Smith Building, 1328 Peachtree Street, N.E. Atlanta, GA 30309

- #### Hygiene Kits






Volunteers are needed on a regular basis to purchase, prepare, and drop off hygiene kits. Completed hygiene kits can be delivered to the church at 1328 Peachtree Street NE, Atlanta GA 30309, Sunday through Thursday from 9:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. at the security desk located at the rear entrance of the church.



Hygiene Kits consist consist of the following supplies:

\- Washcloth

\- Travel Size or Small Shampoo

\- Travel Size or Small Bar Soap

\- Travel Size or Small Lotion

\- Travel Size or Small Toothpaste

\- Toothbrush

\- Disposable Razor





All hygiene kits should be packed in gallon size or sandwich size ziplock style bags. Encouraging or inspirational notes in the bags are optional but appreciated. Make as many hygiene kits as your budget and time allows!



For all question or concerns regarding Hygiene Kits, please reach out to the Community Ministries Operational Director, Jacob Ivey, at [**jivey@firstpresatl.org**](mailto:jivey@firstpresatl.org?subject=Hygiene%20Kit%20Information).

- #### Mailroom






Volunteers are needed to staff the Mailroom, **Mondays through Thursdays from 11:30 a.m. - 3:00 p.m**. Mailroom volunteer will ensure the mail is sorted properly, filed, and distributed to the correct individuals while also engaging in fellowship with Community Ministries clients and each other.



**Location**: 1st Floor of the Smith Building, 1328 Peachtree Street, N.E. Atlanta, GA 30309

- #### Sunday Morning Breakfast






Originally founded in 1981, the Prayer Breakfast at First Presbyterian Church of Atlanta is a well-known part of FPC’s ministry to our unhoused neighbors. During the breakfast, our neighbors can grab a warm meal and engage in fellowship with one another, and the volunteers present. The Prayer Breakfast not only aims to meet the human needs of our unhoused neighbors but also to address the spiritual needs of everyone involved in the breakfast through active community and fellowship.



The breakfast is held at 1328 Peachtree St NE, Atlanta, GA 30309 in **Fifield Hall from 6:30 a.m. to 7:30 a.m.** Volunteers are expected to arrive by **6:00 a.m. and leave by 8:15 a.m.**

- #### Venable Food Market






Volunteers are needed to staff the Venable Food Market on **Tuesdays from 1:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m.** The volunteer will assist with sorting and stocking shelves, helping clients select groceries, and bagging items for clients.



**Location**: 1st Floor of the Smith Building, 1328 Peachtree Street, N.E. Atlanta, GA 30309

- #### Shopping for the Venable Food Market






Volunteers are needed on a regular basis to purchase and drop off food for the food market. Food can be delivered to the church at 1328 Peachtree Street NE, Atlanta GA 30309, Sunday through Thursday from 9:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. at the security desk located at the rear entrance of the church.



[Click here for an updated list of needed items and learn more about the Food Market.](https://www.firstpresatl.org/foodmarket)



Please purchase as much food as you feel comfortable providing and your budget allows!



For all question or concerns regarding Shopping for the Food Market, please reach out to the Community Ministries Operational Director, Jacob Ivey, at [jivey@firstpresatl.org](mailto:jivey@firstpresatl.org?subject=Shopping%20for%20the%20Food%20Market%20Questions).

Item description

- #### Foot Care






Community Ministries is excited to be restarting the historic Foot Care Ministry at First Presbyterian Church of Atlanta! This essential service supports our neighbors, many of whom rely on walking as their primary mode of transportation. Our Foot Care volunteers provide non-clinical care, helping to keep clients' feet clean, healthy, and comfortable. If you’re interested in volunteering with Foot Care, please contact Jacob Ivey at [**jivey@firstpresatl.org**](mailto:jivey@firstpresatl.org?subject=Foot%20Care%20Volunteer%20Info).

## WELCOME TO REDEEMER!

Change is a constant experience in our lives–and sometimes change can be threatening. Especially now.

An ancient poet from the Bible surveyed his world and it truly looked like everything was falling apart. Yet, he was also a person of faith which led him to conclude:

> _“The steadfast love of the Lord never ceases,_
>
> _his mercies never come to an end;_
>
> _they are new every morning.”_
>
> – Lamentations 3:22

That truly is the gift of faith. To have the assurance of God’s love and grace, no matter what. To have the courage to face any challenge, any change, that might come your way. To know that you are never alone. When you are freed from fear, you are free to boldly serve your neighbor and the world. That is the gift we want to share with you!

Whether it’s for support, for prayers, for worship, for learning, or for serving – I invite you to join us in person or on Livestream.

_God Bless, Pastor Mark_

## REDEEMER’S WELCOME STATEMENT

#### We serve a God of abundant grace and generosity. Our worship is centered on the

#### invitation that Christ offers at the communion table: all are welcome in this place. That

#### welcome flows through all we do and say. We open our arms to everyone who comes to

#### share our love of God and all God’s people. We affirm and value the lives of everyone,

#### including all who have been marginalized by ability, age, gender, gender identity and expression,

#### mental or physical health, poverty, race, sexual orientation, or any other circumstance.

#### Let our message be clear:

#### all are welcome to participate fully in the life of our congregation.

# Mission

Grace House is a radically welcoming and inclusive community advocacy ministry that inspires, equips, and engages our campus by modeling Jesus’ love, service, and compassion.

# Vision

Grace House allows students to experience Jesus’ hospitality, connect them with other students on their spiritual journey, help them grow in their faith as they learn how they can transform the world, and empower students to do the work of liberation that God has called them to do.

# About Grace House

Grace \[Coffee\] House is a joint ministry of the Episcopal Diocese of Atlanta and the Southeastern Synod of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America (ELCA). We proudly serve the Georgia Tech community in Atlanta, Georgia.

Grace House is a community of friendship, direction, authenticity, service, and a home away from home.

It may seem on the surface that our welcome is just a cup of coffee but really, our welcome is hope.  Hope is needed in a world that seems fraught with division and hope is needed in the lives of Georgia Tech students.  Hope that they will see the other side of a looming midterm, hope that at some point a social life will return, hope that all this hard work is going to be worth it, hope that one day they might have time to sleep, or hope that there is someplace they can still go to get a free cup of coffee, a smile, and for someone to ask “how’s your week going?”. We want to live into that hope for students in all that we do.

Grace House is an Open and Affirming Christian organization, fully living into our Baptismal covenant, especially that part about

Seeking to Serve Christ in ALL Persons, Loving our Neighbor as Ourself & Striving for Justice and Peace Among ALL People, and Respecting the Dignity of EVERY Human Being.

All Grace House Staff is Safe-Space trained and also trained on Bystander Intervention. We are also a Reconciled in Christ congregation. If at any time you do not feel respected, honored or loved in our home, we would love to talk to you about it and correct it.

# Is Grace House for Me?

Only you can determine if Grace House is a place for you. But I will describe the typical person at Grace House. If you identify with any of these characteristics and want to know more, head on over to the Join tab. You don’t really have to join anything…we just want to get your contact information in so you can get a little more plugged in.  “Join” was merely a convenient word for the menu. :0)

Who is Grace House? “Grace” is a student. Grace is a dropout. They are graduates affiliated with a church. They are lonely and looking for a place to belong. Grace is old. Grace is young. Grace is looking for something different. Something authentic. Something spiritual. Something meaningful.

Grace is tired. Tired of constantly being “on” and looking like they have it all together. Grace is frustrated with what they see around them, and wants to see the world change from its current state. Yet, they are so burned out, sad, fed up, beat up, irritated, and tired that they desperately need a place of refuge. Grace needs a place to come in and just be. Or cry. Or even just color without any pressure to change, compete, work, like, choose, or please. Grace needs a place to be fed literally and spiritually so they can go back out into the world with renewed hope to keep fighting one more day.

​

Grace might be fed up with the church. They may have left the masjid. They may have no idea what these two words even mean because they didn’t grow up with any religious tradition. Grace feels like loving one’s neighbor is important but doesn’t see anyone doing this in real-time. Grace also feels like social justice isn’t a want but a need. A desperate need. Grace thinks Jesus is pretty cool but doesn’t really see anyone living like or modeling the ways of Jesus, especially those who call themselves “Christians”.

​

Finally, Grace doesn’t have all the answers when it comes to faith and doesn’t pretend to. Sometimes, they aren’t even sure they HAVE faith, much less hope. But they want to seek out answers, maybe struggle with them for a bit, but do so in a safe, nurturing environment. Or maybe, Grace just wants to hear an alternative narrative than what they grew up with and decide for themself what to believe. But Grace sure could use a sounding board on that journey.

​

If Grace kinda sounds like you, maybe you should look into Grace House.

#### Pastor Andrew Rickel

Campus Pastor & Executive Director

Rev. Andrew Fritz Rickel (he/him) is a [Lutheran](http://www.elca.org/) Campus Pastor called to [Grace House](https://gracepeople.org/), the Episcopal/Lutheran Campus Ministry in Atlanta.

He mostly grew up in Baltimore Maryland before spending time at Lenoir-Rhyne in Hickory, N.C. when it was still a College. ## Klemis Kitchen

Klemis Kitchen is Georgia Tech’s on-campus food bank. It is named after Tommy Klemis, owner of Junior’s Grill. The goal of Klemis Kitchen is to make sure students are never forced to skip a meal, while simultaneously reducing food waste on campus.

![image](https://star.studentlife.gatech.edu/sites/default/files/2024-12/klemis.png)

![image](https://star.studentlife.gatech.edu/sites/default/files/2024-12/jrs_0.jpg)

**Klemis Kitchen has three main sources of food:**

- A student organization called [Campus Kitchen Project](https://gatech.campuslabs.com/engage/organization/the-campus-kitchen-project) (CKP) recovers leftover food from the dining halls, and packages the food into individual meals
- Various campus departments sponsor shelf-stable food drives throughout the academic year
- The food ministry at [Lutheran Church of the Redeemer](https://www.redeemer.org/) receives donations from several Midtown grocery stores, and they in turn donate portions of their donations to Klemis Kitchen

**There are currently four Klemis Kitchen locations on campus:**

- The Original Klemis Kitchen, located in the Bioquad (directly below the Veterans Resource Center), is available 24 / 7 for students who demonstrate a need for frequent and ongoing access to food. Students may request [Buzzcard access here.](https://forms.microsoft.com/r/PxfGTUsP5J)
- Klemis 489 was our first Klemis Kitchen Outpost. It is in the Clough Undergraduate Learning Center, Room 489. Beginning Spring Semester 2023, Klemis 489 will be open Monday through Friday, 11:00 am – 2:00 pm, for any student who needs to grab a quick meal. (Students who have access to the Original Klemis Kitchen have 24 / 7 access to Klemis 489 as well.)
- The Community Fridge at [Grace House](https://gatech.campuslabs.com/engage/organization/grace-house) (182 Fifth Street, between Techwood and Fowler Streets) can be found under the back deck. The food options is similar to what’s available at the Original Klemis Kitchen, but is open to the entire campus 24 / 7.
- Klemis GSL is in the Graduate Student Lounge on the 3rd floor of the John Lewis Student Center. Graduate students will find a variety of treats (doughnuts, pastries, etc.) in addition to prepared meals.

### My Sister’s House is an overnight shelter for women and children experiencing homelessness.

We provide a safe and healthy environment in which women and children can recover and grow from past experiences that may have contributed towards their present circumstances and work towards healthy relationships with God, themselves, and others, as well as sustainable income and housing. Our team works together with each woman and child to help them address their spiritual, physical, emotional, relational, and vocational needs in a way that is sensitive to the unique needs of each woman and child.

![](https://content.atlantamission.org/content/uploads/2020/06/13223800/top-683x1024.jpg)

## Services

## Serving residents of My Sister’s House:

- Overnight shelter
- Meals
- Counseling
- Life Skills Classes
- Social Service Referrals
- Medical Care
- Childcare
- Vocational Training

_Services based on availability_

_For men, addiction recovery services happen at [The Potter’s House](https://atlantamission.org/potters-house/)._

[Get Directions](https://atlantamission.org/my-sisters-house/)

## My Sister’s House Services and Protocols

## Admissions for Women and Children

Admissions for women and children takes place at Restoration House. [Click here for more information](https://atlantamission.org/restoration-house/#admissions).

**General Requirements**

• Be over the age of 18 unless accompanied by a mother or legal guardian.

• Agree to abide by all guidelines and fully participate in all program activities.

• Be fully detoxified with at least 72 hours since last use of drugs or 24 hours since last use of alcohol.

• Be mentally and physically able to exercise proper personal hygiene and self-care, perform task assignments, and participate in all program functions within a non-medical, non-psychiatric facility.

• Two-bag maximum of personal belongings for each adult, 1 additional bag per child

_Our staff works hard to keep this a safe space for all clients. Privacy is important and your information is confidential._

**Health and Safety**

You are expected to participate in testing for tuberculosis while here. This testing is provided free of charge by community partners, and testing will either take place onsite or you will be transported by staff to a community partner offsite on your scheduled testing day.

**Leaving Campus/Passes**

Clients must have an approved pass in order to leave campus outside of free time. Passes are given for medical appointments, job interviews and work. Please show proof of your appointment/schedule.

**Services**

• You are required to attend class twice daily from 10:30 am-11:30 am and 2:00 pm-3:00 pm. You will be able to choose which classes you would like to attend.

• While you are staying with us, you will meet with a staff member to set 90-day goals to help you work towards your next steps. If you meet those goals and need additional time to work towards income and housing goals your time may be extended. Staff members will meet with you at least biweekly.

• You will be assigned a chore and service activity 5 days out of the week which may include weekends to help keep the community safe clean and running well. This may include but is not limited to deep cleaning, kitchen, industrial laundry, etc.

• 3 Meals will be served in the dining room daily; Food must remain in the dining room. No food is allowed in your room.

# Children, Youth, & Families

[Learn More](https://stlukesatlanta.org/children-youth-and-families)

We value a holistic approach to faith formation and education that engages the whole person. We offer a wide range of programs –from Sunday School and a robust chorister program, to regular social gatherings and outreach volunteer opportunities – for ages 5 through senior year of high school. Nursery care is available each Sunday morning for ages 0 through 4 years old.

It is an honor to accompany you and your family as you journey together in faith. If you have questions about St. Luke’s Children’s, Youth, and Family Ministries, contact The Rev. Megan Swett.

- ##### Sunday



#### Feb 1st 2026  08:30 am - 02:00 pm







### Bell Ringing Practice

- ##### Sunday



#### Feb 1st 2026  09:00 am - 09:30 am







### Children's Chapel & Preparatory Choir (grades pre-K-5)



This year we are centering Children’s Chapel on the 9:00 a.m. service to build on the joyful energy of that gathering. Children in Pre-K through 5th grade are invited to join the entrance procession behind the children’s cross and then proceed to Wilmer Chapel for song, prayer, and worship, rejoining the congregation at the Peace. During Children’s Chapel, Colleen Kingston, Associate Director of Music for Children and Youth, will rehearse Preparatory Choir hymns with the children. If your child would like to participate in Preparatory Choir, they should plan to attend Children’s Chapel each week.





![Children's Chapel & Preparatory Choir (grades pre-K-5)](https://stlukesatlanta.org/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fespacespc.blob.core.windows.net%2F16112%2Fdocs%2Fcf8ab60b-b710-4034-b88d-ebd0ed39cf11.png%3Fsv%3D2025-01-05%26st%3D2026-01-29T04%253A19%253A40Z%26se%3D2026-01-30T04%253A19%253A40Z%26sr%3Db%26sp%3Dr%26sig%3D%252BDKU3XmSqIb9FjCNreHF4ZmOkdNADfMC%252F96MkLwC1Tg%253D&w=3840&q=75)

- ##### Sunday



#### Feb 1st 2026  10:00 am - 11:00 am







### 2025-26 Sunday Formation/Sr. Chorister - Upper Youth (grades 9-12)



Sunday formation class for Upper Youth (grades 9-12). Upper Youth focus on developing their own prophetic voices, and discerning who they are called to be in and for God’s world. Upper Youth begin the formation hour in Room 203. At 10:35 a.m., those who are signed up for Senior Choristers transition to Room 201 for choir rehearsal. Those who do not participate in choir may stay in the classroom for further conversation, or are released.





![2025-26 Sunday Formation/Sr. Chorister - Upper Youth (grades 9-12)](https://stlukesatlanta.org/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fespacespc.blob.core.windows.net%2F16112%2Fevent-image%2F45ebd00c-d7b0-4b49-b84d-e8c58200488e.png%3Fsv%3D2025-01-05%26st%3D2026-01-29T04%253A19%253A40Z%26se%3D2026-01-30T04%253A19%253A40Z%26sr%3Db%26sp%3Dr%26sig%3DiiEYqV7tIai67zEJa4Eki5%252BETq5Eia5XNWgZDqcp5qM%253D&w=3840&q=75)

- ##### Sunday



#### Feb 1st 2026  10:00 am - 11:00 am







### 2025-26 Sunday Formation/Sr. Chorister - Middle Youth (grades 6-8)



Sunday formation class for Middle Youth (grades 6-8). Middle Youth focus on the Scripture and Liturgy of the Christian and Episcopal traditions,
exploring the questions: How do we the stories of our tradition? Why do we do the things we do the way we do them? And, what meaning does what we READ and DO have for who we are and where we belong?

Middle Youth begin the formation hour in Room 205. At 10:35 a.m., those who are signed up for Senior Choristers transition to Room 201 for choir rehearsal. Those who choose not to participate in choir will participate in service projects games, and other activities, or will be released.





![2025-26 Sunday Formation/Sr. Chorister - Middle Youth (grades 6-8)](https://stlukesatlanta.org/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fespacespc.blob.core.windows.net%2F16112%2Fevent-image%2F50ce07d7-5478-4eb0-a941-21d30fe1da32.png%3Fsv%3D2025-01-05%26st%3D2026-01-29T04%253A19%253A40Z%26se%3D2026-01-30T04%253A19%253A40Z%26sr%3Db%26sp%3Dr%26sig%3Dn9iOp4aeRijtmi%252B5%252FVGuMCcQB22qaZxo4165zCl8NEs%253D&w=3840&q=75)

- ##### Sunday



#### Feb 1st 2026  10:00 am - 11:00 am







### 2025-26 Sunday Formation - Children (grades preK-2)



Children in pre-K through 2nd grade meet at 10am in room 111 for an hour of bible stories, craft, song, and games. Children should be picked up by a designated parent or caregiver by 11am.





![2025-26 Sunday Formation - Children (grades preK-2)](https://stlukesatlanta.org/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fespacespc.blob.core.windows.net%2F16112%2Fevent-image%2F95e9aa5a-609c-4347-87d1-404e68208dc2.png%3Fsv%3D2025-01-05%26st%3D2026-01-29T04%253A19%253A40Z%26se%3D2026-01-30T04%253A19%253A40Z%26sr%3Db%26sp%3Dr%26sig%3DO3suLEvEcYDuXQ3SyDoAP1OdU6G%252FqMll%252FJsfAMrrWWE%253D&w=3840&q=75)

DONATION INFORMATION

You have been blessed with the gift of contributing your material resources to the work of the Lord with great joy, eagerness, and generosity. The gift of giving is the special ability that God gives to certain members of the body of Christ to contribute their material resources to the work of the Lord with liberality and cheerfulness.

### **Fundraising Campaigns**

**What is a Capital Campaign?**

In January 2015, Ebenezer Baptist Church launched a five-year fundraising campaign to raise $4.5 million dollars to accomplish major capital improvement and debt reduction goals. These goals include: reducing the mortgage principal and improving building and ground facilities; remodeling the Education Building into a Youth Zone; developing a world-class Children’s Chapel, and College and Church School Ministries, including the modernization of classrooms and access to technology to facilitate learning; and investing in and expanding international ministries and programs.

**How can I support the campaign?**

There are several opportunities for giving to the Ebenezer capital campaign including the Jubilee Legacy Brick Project, Estate Gifts, Ebenezer’s Tympanum bronze relief panel, a one-time capital gift or a multi-year pledge, and the Ebenezer Everywhere Digital Campus. To support the campaign and for additional campaign information, please visit [campaign.historicebenezer.org](http://campaign.historicebenezer.org/).

**Jubilee Brick Campaign**

Celebrate EBC’s past and invest in the future of global social transformation by purchasing a legacy brick to be placed in front of the Historic Ebenezer Baptist Church Horizon Sanctuary and landscaped Prayer Garden. Purchase one or more bricks and cement your family legacy, memorialize a loved one, or recognize your country or organization in the mission of social transformation. Engraved Bricks can be purchased at: 16×16 = $1,000 8×8 = $500 4×8 = $300. [Order Today](http://campaign.historicebenezer.org/index.php/lc/products?search_category_id=3). Contribute to the Jubilee Brick Campaign of the Historic Ebenezer Baptist Church.

**Estate Planning**

Ebenezer Baptist Church provides a way for you to leave a legacy that will support ministry for many years to come. Everyone can make a lasting difference and leave a legacy that supports our faith. Through wise estate planning, significant dollars are normally diverted from taxes, probate, and legal costs and redirected to the Lord’s work (without decreasing the amount of inheritance family members will receive)! EBC’s Christian-based estate planning allows members to make generous gifts to their church while they are living, in addition to what they plan to leave after they depart this life. [Contact us for details.](http://campaign.historicebenezer.org/index.php/other-opportunities)

**Ebenezer’s Tympanum Bronze Relief Panel**

As a member, friend, or both, a legacy gift is an opportunity to make a powerful and enduring declaration of support to “America’s Freedom Church,” Ebenezer Baptist Church. A legacy gift entitles and ensures your name or designated name to be permanently engraved in the Tympanum Bronze Relief Panel affixed to Ebenezer Baptist Church Horizon Sanctuary. [Contact us for details.](http://campaign.historicebenezer.org/index.php/other-opportunities)

**Ebenezer Everywhere Digital Campus**

Ebenezer Everywhere will become an international ministries and programs platform, emerging as a global church campus for reaching and teaching the word of God and message of Jesus Christ.Members, guests, partners, donors, leaders, staff, community, and associates will engage, collaborate, and communicate in real-time ministry services, education, events, and activities that are centered around bringing the hearer to Christ and encouraging and equipping people to use their God-given talents and spiritual gifts for individual growth and social transformation.Through expanded reach, this initiative will transform how ministry is shared through a national and global perspective for serving human and social justice needs. [Contact us for details.](http://campaign.historicebenezer.org/index.php/other-opportunities)

**How can I find out more?**

The Capital Campaign Committee would be happy to assist you in obtaining further information on the programs.

# Solving Homelessness and Hunger in Intown Atlanta

![Current Greatest Needs (6).png](https://static.wixstatic.com/media/740813_feb745509e544218add482b1f88b8db1~mv2.png/v1/fill/w_107,h_116,al_c,q_85,usm_0.66_1.00_0.01,enc_avif,quality_auto/Current%20Greatest%20Needs%20(6).png)

## ABOUT US

### What We Believe

Our mission is to prevent and reverse homelessness and hunger in Intown Atlanta. We believe in human dignity and work every day to help our neighbors meet their most essential needs – housing and food. We specialize in helping unhoused people who face major barriers make the transition to their own homes, and we provide easy access to food for any who need it. We walk alongside the neighbors we serve – respecting each individual's pace and personal decisions.

[OUR STORY](https://www.intowncares.org/our-story)

![95326497_3189103274454389_6885225560700616704_o.jpg](https://static.wixstatic.com/media/740813_5dbf086552264d8b9c6de2ce3c0007e3~mv2.jpg/v1/fill/w_960,h_867,al_c,q_85,enc_avif,quality_auto/740813_5dbf086552264d8b9c6de2ce3c0007e3~mv2.jpg)

![pantry image.png](https://static.wixstatic.com/media/740813_d88c33c461bc4c76911f9276a01cfa90~mv2.png/v1/fill/w_6,h_745,al_c,q_85,enc_avif,quality_auto/740813_d88c33c461bc4c76911f9276a01cfa90~mv2.png)

### At The Table

When you don’t know where your next meal will come from, it’s hard to focus on other parts of your life that need attention.

To alleviate food insecurity for Atlanta neighbors, we make food available twice a week at our pantry – and make deliveries to neighbors who can’t get to the pantry.

​

Nourishment is our first priority. We work hard to source healthy food that is often unaffordable and sometimes hard to find – from fresh produce to meat, dairy, and bread. We also supply toiletry kits, pet food, and other essential household items.

## [FOOD PROGRAMS](https://www.intowncares.org/what-we-do)

### Home Again

![a8fef757-275f-b1f7-b496-09134b43c1cb (2).png](https://static.wixstatic.com/media/740813_5664842be8e24fccb6d53031f84ed5ee~mv2.png/v1/fill/w_480,h_320,al_c,q_85,usm_0.66_1.00_0.01,enc_avif,quality_auto/a8fef757-275f-b1f7-b496-09134b43c1cb%20(2).png)

We focus primarily on helping neighbors who face the greatest obstacles to housing, including individuals who have been unable to stabilize with traditional pathways to housing.

​

The official term for what these neighbors experience is “chronic homelessness.” This means they are:

- repeatedly “unhoused” or lack housing for more than a year; and

- dealing with a disability (mental or physical) or substance use​


​

We help neighbors navigate a complex journey. Our model is based on Housing First – the federal best practice that emphasizes placing people directly into housing and addressing personal obstacles after they are housed rather than as a precondition of housing. After clients are housed we continue to provide case management services to support the transition.
